Award.AwardTitle: A Study of the Faint Debris Remnant of Large Galaxy, Small Galaxy Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Galaxies can grow bigger by accreting smaller, neighboring galaxies. The debris from such events leaves trails of stars in the outskirts of the growing galaxy. By analyzing the debris, scientists hope to reconstruct how these tumultuous events unfolded. The starlight from the debris is extremely faint at optical wavelengths. Observations of such low-surface-brightness debris have been possible only recently. The team will use cutting-edge theory and simulations to catalog the kinds of structures expected for the debris. The team's statistician will isolate the structures that help the most with the reconstructions. Observers will then look for such telltale structures. Senior team members will train junior members. During her colloquium visits nation-wide, the PI will discuss barriers facing minorities in science. Through a partnership with a non-profit, the team will engage with underserved high school students in New York City.

The team will study debris structures left in galaxy halos by the destruction of small, accreted galaxies. The goals of the team are to (1) make theoretical estimates of the expected structures, (2) create libraries of synthetic surveys of simulated galaxy halos, and (3) develop and test statistical measures of various properties of the structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

How do galaxies form and evolve? This is one of the big questions that Astronomers try to answer by looking at images of galaxies across the night sky. Hubble developed a description of the main morphological features of galaxies early in the 20th century which classifies galaxies into three main types:  "spiral", "elliptical" or "irregular". However, when astronomers looked very carefully at the outskirts of galaxies, they found additional structures at very low surface brightness beyond the bulk of the light in many cases. The work funded by this grant is inspired by the existence of these encircling features, and the prospect of finding many more as futures observational surveys probe to ever deeper surface brightness limits.

The main way that astronomers think these low surface brightness features are buit up is by larger galaxies attracting and cannibalizing smaller ones: the faint structures around galaxies are the remnants of their prior meals! The exciting consequence of these eating habits is that there is a lot of information encoded in the debris left behind.  Over the years, prior work by PI Johnston (and others) have demonstrated how the morphologies, scales and surface brightness of debris from the destruction of a small galaxy encodes the orbit on which it was moving, its original luminosity and mass. Hence, by disgnosing the faint structures around galaxies we can learn something about their histories.

While this has been undertood conceptually and analytically for some time, automated algorithms to analyze debris characteristics did not exist. In this grant we made the first such algorithm, capable of classifying debris into different morphologies (that reflect the orbit) and measuring luminosities and scales. We have started a collaboration with one of the current observational surveys to test out algorithm. The ultimate goal is to use it to help contrain galacitc histories, populations and orbits with future generations of surveys.

 

Broader Impact 

The grant provided partial support and training for two PhD students during their graduate studies. Boht have now successfully graduated and gone on to postdoctoral positions in Astronomy. It has also supported one postbac student as she transitions form undergraduate work. She is currently applying to graduate school.

Graduate student Sarah Pearson used some funds form this grant to launch the YouTube channel, "Space with Sarah".
